news.title: High Court jails businessman Maburutse for contempt in bitter feud over Matebeleland Engineering (Pvt) Ltd
news.content:
By Mary Taruvinga

The High Court has found businessman Regis Maburutse in contempt of court and sentenced him to six months in prison, wholly suspended on condition he complies with a 2023 order barring him from interfering in the affairs of Matebeleland Engineering (Pvt) Ltd.

Justice Regis Dembure ruled that Maburutse had wilfully and blatantly defied an earlier judgment by Justice Gladys Mhuri, which interdicted him from disrupting fellow director and shareholder Tony Renato Sarpo.

The 1st respondent continues to hold himself out as such [a director], blatantly illegally, and continues to usurp the functions of the board, Sarpo told the court in his affidavit, accusing Maburutse of forging records, harassing employees and even rebranding the companys signage in Harare and Bulawayo under new names in a bid to sidestep the order.

Maburutses legal defence collapsed after the court struck out his opposing affidavit, ruling it had been improperly commissioned. Justice Dembure declared, Once an affidavit is found to have been improperly commissioned, it is a nullity. Nothing can flow from it.

The court accepted Sarpos claims as unchallenged and stressed that its authority had to be respected. The application must succeed as against the first respondent, Dembure ruled.

In contrast, Wayne Williams, cited as the second respondent, was cleared of contempt. The judge found the 2023 order imposed no clear obligations on him.

There can be no contempt of court to talk about in these circumstances, he said.

The ruling marks another dramatic twist in the long-running shareholder war over Matebeleland Engineering, a dispute that has seen allegations of forgery, asset stripping, and multiple appeals  most of which Sarpo has won.

Maburutse will avoid prison if he immediately complies with the High Court order, but Justice Dembure warned that continued defiance would trigger the six-month custodial sentence at Chikurubi Maximum Prison.
news.description:
By Mary Taruvinga The High Court has found businessman Regis Maburutse in contempt of court and sentenced him to six months in prison, wholly suspended on condition he complies with a 2023 order barring him from interfering in the affairs of Matebeleland Engineering (Pvt) Ltd. Justice Regis Dembure ruled that Maburutse had “wilfully and blatantly”

The post High Court jails businessman Maburutse for contempt in bitter feud over Matebeleland Engineering (Pvt) Ltd appeared first on NewZimbabwe.com.

news.title: High Court rejects murder suspect’s bid for discharge, rules there is a case to answer
news.content:
By Mary Taruvinga

A man accused of fatally assaulting another in Damofalls last December has been ordered to stand trial after the High Court refused to dismiss his case, ruling that the State had established a prima facie case against him.

Justice Gibson Mandaza dismissed Wairo Wairos application for discharge at the close of the States case, saying evidence from witnesses linked him directly to the death of David Sengai, who died after being severely beaten.

At this stage of the proceedings, the simple question is: on the record, is there evidence against the accused person which requires a reply from him? I take the view that indeed there is evidence before the court, the judge said.

Wairo is charged with murder under section 47(1) of the Criminal Law (Codification and Reform) Act. Prosecutors allege that on 23 December 2023, Wairo and three accomplices assaulted Sengai with open hands and fists, causing head injuries from which he later died.

Key witness Noleen Goro, who once dated the accused, told the court she saw Wairo slapping Sengai so hard he fell to the ground while others dragged him by his shirt. She later called a passerby, Tafadzwa Paundi, to help the victim.

Defence lawyers attacked Goros credibility, calling her a self-confessed alcoholic, but the judge found her testimony consistent with that of the investigating officer and Paundi. Calling her names does not detract from her testimony, which is consistent, Mandaza J ruled.

The judge stressed that at this stage the State was only required to show a prima facie case, not proof beyond reasonable doubt. Once a prima facie case has been established, the evidential burden will shift to the accused to adduce evidence in order to escape conviction, he said.

The trial will now proceed to the defence case, with Wairo expected to answer to the murder charge.
news.description:
By Mary Taruvinga A man accused of fatally assaulting another in Damofalls last December has been ordered to stand trial after the High Court refused to dismiss his case, ruling that the State had established a prima facie case against him. Justice Gibson Mandaza dismissed Wairo Wairo’s application for discharge at the close of the

news.title: Baba Harare returns to Jiti after sour gospel experience
news.content:
By Tapiwa Svondo

Baba Harare has returned to his Jiti roots, abandoning the gospel path he had pursued for the past year.

The musician, who a year ago stunned fans by announcing his decision to leave secular music for gospel, revealed the disrespect and exploitation he faced within the gospel industry. He accused some church event organisers of refusing to pay artists after performances.

In a Facebook post, Baba Harare, who had rebranded himself asKing Davidduring his gospel stint, said many promoters expect gospel musicians to perform for free, arguing that payment shouldnt matter because its for the Kingdom.

Ive been blessed to experience both worlds the secular stage and the gospel stage. From a ministerial perspective, gospel concerts are powerful. They spread the Word, they win souls, and they glorify God. But from a business perspective, its a different story.

Often, people hide under the idea that because youre ministering for the Kingdom, payment shouldnt matter. But lets be honest: I am not only a Christian, I am also a human being and an artist. This is my work, my livelihood, and I need to survive beyond the stage, wrote Baba Harare.

He warned upcoming musicians not to rely solely on gospel shows, citing widespread exploitation.

I would not advise any upcoming artist to rely exclusively on gospel shows. Too many times Ive been booked to minister at church events and conferences, only to struggle afterwards to recover even my basic expenses.

Shame on those who exploit others in the name of Christ. Lets do better as a community.

The musician also shared a flyer from a recent gospel event where, after performing, he was met with rudeness when he followed up on a promised payment.

Let me give you a recent example. On Friday, I went to minister at a church (see flyer attached). I didnt charge them a performance fee. All I asked for was a token of $200 to cover my fuel and expenses. Instead of being met with understanding, I was met with rudeness. Suddenly, I was no longer a brother in Christ, but mocked and called a comrade (screenshot attached).

This is not Kingdom behaviour. This is not how we build each other. And its one of the reasons the gospel industry struggles to move forward,lack of respect, lack of accountability, and non-payment of artists.

Im not posting this to attack anyone, but to spark a real conversation. We dont talk about this enough. If youre a promoter, a church, or an organiser, please do better. Honour your word. Respect the artist. Support the ministry in every sense, said Baba Harare.
news.description:
By Tapiwa Svondo Baba Harare has returned to his Jiti roots, abandoning the gospel path he had pursued for the past year. The musician, who a year ago stunned fans by announcing his decision to leave secular music for gospel, revealed the “disrespect” and exploitation he faced within the gospel industry. He accused some church

news.title: Warriors fall to Rwanda as winless streak continues
news.content:
By Sports Reporter

Rwandas Gilbert Mugishas 40th-minute strike was all the team needed to secure a 1-0 win over Zimbabwe in a Group C Africa 2026 World Cup Qualifier at Orlando Stadium on Tuesday afternoon.

Zimbabwe produced a lacklustre first-half performance, failing to create any meaningful chances or register a single shot on target.

The Warriors improved slightly in the second half following the introduction of Tymon Machope and Bill Antonio, who replaced Tawanda Maswanhise and Prosper Padera at the restart.

Their golden opportunity came in the 72nd minute when Machope pulled a pass back for Tawanda Chirewa, who failed to convert despite the Rwandan goalkeeper being out of position.

The result piles more pressure on Warriors coach Michael Nees, who was heavily criticised after Fridays defeat to Benin.

Zimbabwe remains the only winless side in Group C, and Tuesdays loss all but ended their hopes of qualifying for the 2026 World Cup.

Of the eight matches played so far, the Warriors have collected just four points out of a possible 24. Since 2010, Zimbabwe has managed only two wins in 29 World Cup Qualifier fixtures.
news.description:

Zimbabwe produced a lacklustre first-half performance, failing to create any meaningful chances or register a single shot on target. The

The post Warriors fall to Rwanda as winless streak continues appeared first on NewZimbabwe.com.

news.title: In-house vs External Training in Health and Social Care
news.content:
By Dr Richard Dune

Why blended learning strategies are becoming a compliance essential for health, social care and education providers

In the UKs heavily regulated health and social care environment, training is not a nice-to-have, but a non-negotiable requirement. For organisations operating under the scrutiny of theCare Quality Commission(CQC), local authorities and service commissioners, training forms the foundation of workforce development, governance, and regulatory compliance.

Whether its safeguarding, infection prevention, medication administration, or supervision and appraisal, training must be consistent, compliant, and aligned with both operational needs and legal frameworks. Yet many leaders still face a critical question:

Should training be delivered in-house or outsourced to external providers?

In this article,Dr Richard Duneexamine the strengths and weaknesses of each approach, explores why blended learning models are becoming the preferred option, and highlights how digital compliance systems such asComplyPlusare helping health, social care, and education providers deliver training that is strategic, efficient, and inspection-ready.

Health and social care training is not merely a workforce development function. It is a pillar of compliance. Providers are required to deliver training that enables staff to perform safely, ethically, and effectively across diverse settings, be it a residential care home, healthcare clinic, a supported living facility or a domiciliary service.

Effective training programmes must support:

Failure to provide this can result in enforcement action, reputational damage, or poor inspection ratings.

In-house training strengthens internal capacity by enabling staff to deliver tailored learning. The following outlines what it is, its advantages, and the challenges organisations need to address:

In-house trainingrefers to learning and development delivered internally by a providers own staff. Typically, trainers hold credentials such asTrain the Traineror the Award in Education and Training (AET) and are responsible for cascading knowledge across the workforce.

In-house delivery is commonly used for:

This model enables organisations to create training experiences that reflect their internal processes, service users, and local context.

When implemented well, in-house training offers multiple benefits:

By using internal trainers, organisations can ensure training is deeply embedded in practice and reflective of their governance and compliance structures.

However, internal training has its limitations, including:

To be effective, in-house training requires robust planning, adequate resourcing, and integration with digital compliance systems like LMS and TMS platforms.

External training brings accredited expertise and fresh perspectives into organisations. The following outlines what it is, its advantages, and the challenges providers should consider:

External training refers to programmes delivered by third-party providers, including independent consultants or established training organisations. These may offer accredited qualifications, CPD courses, or modules for regulatory compliance.

External training formats range from:

External training is often used for high-risk, regulated, or highly specialised areas.

When used strategically, external training offers several high-value benefits that can enhance both compliance and service quality:

External training is ideal for topics that require independent verification, specialist accreditation, or knowledge outside the organisations internal capacity.

Despite its benefits, external training also presents practical and strategic challenges that providers must carefully consider:

External training is a powerful tool, but must be strategically selected, reviewed, and quality-assured to deliver value and compliance assurance.

The COVID-19 pandemic transformed how providers approach training. With restrictions on face-to-face interaction, organisations turned to e-learning platforms and digital compliance systems to maintain training obligations.

The result? A lasting shift in how training is delivered.

As digital learning becomes more embedded in training strategies, providers are seeing a range of measurable benefits across compliance, efficiency, and accessibility:

Digital training has now become a core component of compliance infrastructure, bridging the gap between in-house and external delivery.

Recognising the benefits and drawbacks of both models, many providers are adopting blended training strategies, combining in-house training, external expertise, and digital integration.

This model aligns closely with regulatory expectations, supporting cost control, consistency, and quality assurance.

Blended training brings together the strengths of in-house delivery, the expertise of external providers, and the efficiency of digital integration to create a comprehensive, compliant, and sustainable training strategy.

In-house training is typically used for:

External training is usually applied to:

Digital integration enhances both models through:

This blended approach ensures training is flexible, high-quality, and aligned with governance and compliance requirements, regardless of how its delivered.

A blended training strategy enables organisations to leverage the strengths of both internal and external delivery, supported by digital tools that enhance oversight and accountability. Key benefits include:

Together, these benefits make blended learning a strategic, scalable, and sustainable approach to workforce development and regulatory compliance.

Before deciding which training model to adopt, providers should ask:

These questions should be integrated into your broader governance and compliance strategy.

At The Mandatory Training Group, we developedComplyPlusto support providers in building compliant, blended training systems.

Our all-in-one platform includes:

Whether you run a care home, a multi-site nursery, a supported living service, or a complex group organisation, ComplyPlus helps you combine in-house capability with external assurance, all within one integrated platform.

The debate isnt in-house vs external training. Its about knowing when to use each and how to tie them together through smart governance, digital systems, and compliance strategy.

The most resilient organisations are those that treat training as a strategic compliance function, not just an HR process or a tick box exercise.

Delivering the right training mix is more than a choice. Its a compliance requirement and a mark of great leadership.

news.title: Kadewere faces disciplinary action over heated confrontation with journalist
news.content:
By Sports Reporter

Warriors striker Tinotenda Kadewere will face disciplinary action following his attack on journalist Yvonne Mangunda at Orlando Stadium, South Africa, on Monday.

The incident happened during the teams training session ahead of Tuesdays clash against Rwanda.

Kadewere threatened Mangunda, accusing her of negative coverage.

Following interventions by teammates, Kadewere later apologised to Mangunda for his behaviour.

ZIFA issued a statement condemning Kadeweres behaviour.

The Zimbabwe Football Association notes with deep regret the incident that occurred at Orlando Stadium during the Warriors media open training session, involving national team player Tinotenda Kadewere and journalist Yvonne Mangunda.

ZIFA strongly condemns any form of abuse towards the media. Journalists are a vital part of the game, and we are committed to ensuring they carry out their duties without fear or intimidation.

The player has apologised to Ms Mangunda, and an amicable understanding between the two parties has been reached. The matter is being addressed through the appropriate disciplinary processes by both the team management and the Association.

We take full responsibility for upholding the highest standards of conduct within our teams and reaffirm our commitment to respectful engagement with all stakeholders, read the ZIFA statement.
news.description:
By Sports Reporter Warriors striker Tinotenda Kadewere will face disciplinary action following his attack on journalist Yvonne Mangunda at Orlando Stadium, South Africa, on Monday. The incident happened during the team’s training session ahead of Tuesday’s clash against Rwanda. Kadewere threatened Mangunda, accusing her of negative coverage. Following interventions by teammates, Kadewere later apologised to

The post Kadewere faces disciplinary action over heated confrontation with journalist  appeared first on NewZimbabwe.com.

news.title: Zimbabweans seeking  non-immigrant visas to apply in South Africa as suspension continues – U.S Embassy announces
news.content:
By Thandiwe Garusa

ZIMBABWEANS seeking non-immigrant visas can now apply only in South Africa, the United States Embassy in Harare has announced.

Last month, the U.S Embassy announced suspension of all routine immigrant and non-immigrant visa services, except for most diplomatic and official visas in Harare.

The embassy later extended the validity of visas for Zimbabwean applicants working as crew members on ships or airlines to 24 months with multiple entry, with an option of applying outside Zimbabwe due to the pause on immigrant and non-immigrant visa services.

In a statement Monday, the U.S embassy said the pause remains in effect and Zimbabweans seeking non-immigrant visas can only apply in Johannesburg, while non-residents must use embassies in their countries of habitual residence.

The pause on visa services in Zimbabwe remains in effect.

Zimbabwean residents applying for non-immigrant visas may only apply at the U.S. Consulate General in Johannesburg.

If you are not a resident of Zimbabwe, you must apply at a U.S. embassy or consulate in your country of habitual residence, the statement reads.

The authorities also warned of possible long wait times, stricter qualification hurdles for applicants who schedule non-immigrant visa interviews at a U.S. embassy or consulate outside their country of nationality.

Applicants who schedule non-immigrant visa interviews at a U.S. embassy or consulate outside their country of nationality or residence may face greater difficulty qualifying for the visa. Visa application fees are nonrefundable.

Meanwhile, those applying for visas were recently directed to adjust the privacy settings of their personal social media accounts to public to facilitate vetting necessary to establish their identity and admissibility.

By Thandiwe Garusa ZIMBABWEANS seeking non-immigrant visas can now apply only in South Africa, the United States Embassy in Harare has announced. Last month, the U.S Embassy announced suspension of all routine immigrant and non-immigrant visa services, except for most diplomatic and official visas in Harare. The embassy later extended the validity of visas for

news.title: Harare residents rally against council’s sale of Otto Road to Mnangagwa’s son – warn of impact to vulnerable groups
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

HIGHLANDS residents are up in arms with the Harare City Council over the planned sale of a public road in the suburb to an individual believed to be President Emmerson Mnangagwas son.

Harare City Council placed a notice recently in the newspaper regarding the sale of a portion of land on Otto Road in Highlands. The potential buyer of the land, believed to be Collins Mnangagwa, is constructing a multi-storey building in the area and intends to close part of the public road.

The residents have been given a month to lodge objections and reasons with the City Council regarding the land.

The Highlands Residents Association has, via a petition, objected to the sale of the portion of the road by the City Council.

We, the undersigned residents and community members of Highlands and surrounding areas, hereby submit our formal objection to the proposed permanent road closure of a portion of Otto Road (i.e. Otto Drive, being the road connecting Willowmead Lane to Collins Avenue hereinafter referred to as Otto Road as per the public notice), Highlands, Harare, as advertised in the Public Notice placed in The Herald on Tuesday 2 September 2025, read the petition.

The residents lashed out at the City Council for the lack of transparency in the process, arguing that the sale of the land deprives the public of the benefits it carries.

Otto Road is public land. Its permanent closure and subsequent sale would deprive current and future residents of their right to access and benefit from public infrastructure.

Otto Road provides a safe and established route for domestic workers, security guards, gardeners, pedestrians, cyclists, schoolchildren, walkers and joggers. Closing it will force vulnerable users onto busier, more dangerous routes.

Many people who rely on Otto Road do not own cars. Closure would disproportionately harm women, children, and low-income workers who depend on safe non-motorised routes.

The proposed closure appears to serve private interests at the expense of the broader community. Council has a duty to uphold transparency and protect public assets for collective benefit, read the petition.
news.description:
By Staff Reporter HIGHLANDS residents are up in arms with the Harare City Council over the planned sale of a public road in the suburb to an individual believed to be President Emmerson Mnangagwa’s son. Harare City Council placed a notice recently in the newspaper regarding the sale of a portion of land on Otto
